title: Asthma Attack
summary: Managing acute asthma attacks with rescue inhalers and recognizing when emergency help is needed.

steps.title: Recognize Asthma Attack
steps.description: Signs include: severe wheezing, persistent coughing, difficulty speaking in full sentences, chest tightness, blue lips/fingernails, anxiety. Person may be hunched over struggling to breathe.

steps.title: Help with Rescue Inhaler
steps.description: Help person use their quick-relief inhaler (usually blue). Shake well, exhale fully, seal lips around mouthpiece, press down while inhaling deeply, hold breath 10 seconds. Use spacer if available.

steps.title: Position for Easier Breathing
steps.description: Sit person upright, leaning slightly forward with arms supported on table or knees. Loosen tight clothing. Keep calm - anxiety worsens breathing. Open windows for fresh air if not triggered by outdoor allergens.

steps.title: Continue Inhaler as Directed
steps.description: Give 2-6 puffs of rescue inhaler every 20 minutes for up to 1 hour. If person has asthma action plan, follow it. Call 911 if not improving after first treatment or getting worse.

steps.title: Monitor and Seek Help
steps.description: Call 911 if: lips/fingernails turning blue, cannot speak in short phrases, inhaler not helping, peak flow below 50% of normal, extreme anxiety or drowsiness. Continue inhaler while waiting.

warnings: Severe asthma can be fatal - don't delay calling 911 if person is in distress
Blue lips or extreme difficulty breathing requires immediate emergency care
Never leave person alone during severe attack
whenToSeekHelp: Call 911 if rescue inhaler isn't helping after 15-20 minutes
Seek immediate help for blue lips or inability to speak
Call 911 if person becomes drowsy or stops wheezing suddenly (airways closing)
preventionTips: Always carry rescue inhaler and check expiration dates
Take controller medications daily as prescribed
Identify and avoid personal asthma triggers
